State-of-art carbon and graphene family nanomaterials for asphalt modification
Shenghua Wu∗ and Omar Tahri
Department of Civil, Coastal, and Environmental Engineering, University of South Alabama, Mobile, AL, USA
(Received 21 December 2018; accepted 7 July 2019 )
Carbon and graphene family nanomaterials have attracted more attentions and interests in the asphalt modification research due to their superior mechanical properties. This paper provides the state-of-art review of various graphene synthesis methods (chemical vapour deposition, exfoliation, thermal decomposition, unzipping, and reduction of graphite oxide) and recent studies on typical carbon and graphene family nanomaterials (nanoplatelets and graphene oxide) and carbon nanotube used for asphalt modification towards road engineering application. The effect of each nanomaterial on the asphalt binder is explored with respect to the rutting resistance (high-temperature property), fatigue cracking resistance (intermediate temperature property), and thermal cracking resistance (low-temperature property), respectively. Additionally, various blending methods for dispersing nanomaterials into the asphalt and the cost-effectiveness of each graphene family material are discussed.
Keywords: carbon and graphene family nanomaterials; carbon nanotube; nanoplatelets; graphene oxide; asphalt binder; property

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Asphalt accounts for 5–7% of asphalt mixture by weight, but it plays a critical role in the mixtures’ performance with regard to compatibility and adhesion with different types of aggregates, workability at various production temperatures, and durability at varying climatic conditions. Modern virgin asphalt is produced through refining petroleum, which is a hydrocarbon material that behaves differently at different temperatures. In order to achieve the desired performances of asphalt under severe climatic and traffic loading conditions, researchers have introduced various types of additives and modifiers into the asphalt. These additives and modifiers cover a wide range, such as plastic waste, crumb rubber, polymers, wax, zeolite, and rejuvenating oils, which is designed to meet the performance requirements, including stability at high temperature to avoid rutting, sufficient resistance to fatigue cracking under repeated traffic at ambient temperature, as well as flexibility and adequate relaxation at low temperature to prevent thermal cracking (Costa, Peralta, Oliveira, & Silva, 2017; Kim, Lee, & Amirkhanian, 2011; Saberi, Fakhri, & Azami, 2017; Wu, Zhang, Shen, & Muhunthan, 2018).
With a rapid development of nanotechnology, nanomaterials have been increasingly used for asphalt modification, such as nanoclay (Abdullah et al., 2016; De Melo & Triches, 2017; El-Shafie, Ibrahim, & Rahman, 2012; Golestani, Nejad, & Galooyak, 2012; You et al., 2011), nanosilica (Al-Omari, Taamneh, Khasawneh, & Al-Hosainat, 2019; Bala, Napiah, &

sections.text:
Kamaruddin, 2018; Crucho, Neves, Capitão, & Picado-Santos, 2018; Enieb & Diab, 2017; Guo, Sun, Dai, & Chen, 2016; Yao et al., 2013), nanofibre (Khattak, Khattab, & Rizvi, 2013; Khattak, Khattab, Rizvi, & Zhang, 2012; Rizvi, Khattak, Madani, & Khattab, 2016), and nanometals (ZnO, Al2O3 and Fe2O3) (Ali et al., 2017; Hamedi, 2017; Pirmohammad, Majd-Shokorlou, & Amani, 2019; Zhang, Gao, Guo, Zhao, & Yu, 2018). These mentioned nanomaterials are measured in one billionth dimension, which results in a significantly increased surface area as compared to conventional engineering materials. Due to their unique texture characteristics and physical properties, the modified asphalt binders with nanomaterials present various performances. Table 1 summarises the morphology of nanoclay, nanosilica, nanofibre, and nanometals in terms of SEM image, and the effect of each nanomaterial on the asphalt binders’ properties. As shown, all nanomaterials have “reinforcing” effects on asphalt binders, which is evident by an increased stiffness and viscosity, and thus an enhanced resistance to rutting and possibly a better resistance to fatigue cracking of asphalt. However, the low-temperature property of modified asphalt seems to be compromised by nanomaterials to some extent (Bala et al., 2018; Golestani et al., 2012; Tsantilis, Baglieri, & Santagta, 2018).
Recently, there is an increasingly more interests in graphene family nanomaterials and carbon nanotube (CNT) in asphalt community due to their surprising physical properties such as stiffness, strength and electric conductivity (Liu et al., 2014; Suárez-Iglesias, Collado, Oulego, & Díaz, 2017; Wang, 2016). Different from nanoclay, nanosilica, nanofibre, and nanometal, graphene is formed by hexagonal rings of sp2-hybridised carbon atoms (Tsantilis et al., 2018), which is a novel two-dimensional (2D) monolayer material consisting of a honeycomb lattice structure, as shown in Figure 1.
There are abundant products that are acclaimed as graphene materials, such as pristine graphene, few-layer graphene, multilayer graphene, single-walled CNTs, graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs), and graphene oxide (GO). However, there exists a gap in understanding how these nanomaterials differ from each other. The objective of this paper is to provide a state-of-art review of
Road Materials and Pavement Design 3

sections.heading: 4 S. Wu and O. Tahri
sections.text: research on the carbon and graphene family nanomaterials used for asphalt binders, by first-time compiling all the literatures relevant to the topic of asphalt modification. The origins of graphene and synthesis method of each graphene type are discussed, followed by the effect of typical carbon and graphene family nanomaterials on the asphalt binders’ performance with respect to rutting resistance (high-temperature property), fatigue cracking resistance (intermediate temperature property), and thermal cracking resistance (low-temperature property), which are the most concerns to our asphalt pavement community. Additionally, this paper will discuss the handling and mixing graphene family nanomaterials into asphalt to achieve good dispersion and compatibility with asphalt, as well as cost–benefit analysis of graphene family nanomaterials used for asphalt modification.

sections.heading: 2. Origins and synthesis of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials
sections.text:
The first time to produce graphene was proposed by Novoselov et al. (2005), which was famous for the Scotch tape method. Essentially, this method peels monolayers into a single-layer graphene. However, the tape method is inefficient and less useful for a large-scale production. Since then, numerous methods have been developed to produce graphene, which can be categorised into five major synthesis methods: chemical vapour deposition (CVD), exfoliation, thermal decomposition, unzipping, and reduction of graphite oxide. Table 2 summarises the source, pros and cons, and main manufacturing procedure for each synthesis method.
CVD method is to dissolve carbon into chemical solution and grow the graphene with controlled layers and sizes through a chemical evaporation and air flow procedure (Ma & Chen, 2015). Liu et al. (2014) realised the growth of 3D graphene in a chamber quartz reactor using the Ni foam as catalyst and template, because 2D graphene is vulnerable to crack, and integrating 2D graphene components into 3D structures can increase their strength and stiffness. Other templates such as MgO and ZnO can be used, and a significant amount of chemical solutions is needed for CVD method. It is interesting to note that researchers produced graphene using asphalt as a carbon source (Liu et al., 2014), and other inexpensive carbon-rich materials can be also used for the CVD method.
Exfoliation originally is a repeated peeling process from highly pyrolytic graphite (Gayathri, Jayabal, Kottaisamy, & Ramakrishnan, 2014), which is called as mechanical exfoliation using Scotch tape method, but it cannot provide a mass production. A chemical solution exfoliation has been proposed to produce graphene sheets in a mass production, which involves two steps: the graphite is dissolved into solvent solution and then graphene is synthesised by sonication. Kosynkin et al. (2009) proposed the unzipping method which consists of cutting and unravelling

the multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) side walls to get single-layer graphene. They suspended MWCNTs into solvent and then oxidised MWCNT to nanoribbons, which was similar to the concept of chemical exfoliation method.
Thermal decomposition method was firstly reported by Badmi in 1965. They heated bulk silicon carbide (SiC) at a high temperature of more than 2180°C in vacuum to remove Si and then to obtain a graphite lattice. Later researchers modified this method using lower temperature in ultra-high vacuum or in argon environment (Mishra, Boeckl, Motta, & Iacopi, 2016). High quality of graphene can be obtained, but the manufacturing cost remains high due to additional micromachining (Mishra et al., 2016).
GO is similar to graphite with respect to layered structure, but the plane of carbon atoms in graphite oxide contains oxygen groups (Pei & Cheng, 2012). Chemical oxidation of graphite to GO followed by the reduction process is the commonly used method for mass scale production of graphene or reduced graphene oxide (rGO) (De Silva, Huang, Joshi, & Yoshimura, 2017). GO was prepared by exfoliation of graphite using modified Hummer’s method, as follows: graphite is initially oxidised to obtain highly soluble GO that is reduced in a second step. This technique could produce a high quantity of graphene materials with low cost. However, the graphene flakes obtained by such method generally leads to low-quality materials with many defects and vacancies because oxides always remain at the graphene’s surface and edge. This is why other non-oxidative techniques were proposed for preparing large quantities of graphene materials (Leroux, Bergamini, Ababou, Le Breton, & Hapiot, 2015; Sharma et al., 2017).
As shown in Table 2, chemical solutions are in high demand in the production of graphene, which could create significant environmental impacts if chemical are not handled appropriately. Green practices are developed in recent years to minimise using chemicals or to use green reductants (De Silva et al., 2017). Furthermore, cost is one of the most important criterion that limits a wide application of graphene, and thus researchers are seeking alternative synthesis methods and diverse cheaper sources of carbon, such as sugar, asphalt, wood lignin, and other recycled materials that are rich in carbon (Xu et al., 2013). More types of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials that contain metals and other oxides are currently under research (Yan et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 3. Carbon and graphene family nanomaterials used for asphalt binders
sections.text:
Carbon and graphene family nanomaterials have been applied in several fields, such as sensing technology, electrocatalysts, spectrometry, and environmental remediation, due to its superior electric, optical, mechanical and thermal properties (Edwards, 2014). However, the study on their application in the asphalt field just started in recent years and developed rapidly. Like any additives introduced into pure petroleum asphalt, questions are raised such as: How much carbon and graphene family nanomaterial is needed by the weight of asphalt? How are they compatible with different sources of asphalt? How do they affect the property and performance of asphalt? These questions will be answered in this review paper.
Literatures collected in this study have indicated that most researchers have studied on CNT, GNPs, and GO for asphalt modifications. Although CNT is not a type of graphene, it can be thought of as a sheet of graphene rolled into a cylinder. Only one literature was found for adding graphene into porous asphalt, which is said to increase the strength of asphalt mixture and increase porous asphalt pavement performance (Aravind, Isac, & Aparajith, 2018). However, it is unclear whether graphene used in their study is pristine graphene or other types. This review paper focuses on three common types of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials for asphalt modification, as discussed below.
8 S. Wu and O. Tahri
3.1. Carbon nanotubes CNTs are one-atom-thin sheets of graphite shaped into a hollow cylinder, which have superior mechanical properties by exhibiting high tensile strength (Yang & Tighe, 2013). Most prominently investigated in two forms, single and multi-wall nanotubes, as presented in Figure 2(a) and (b), respectively. Table 3 summarises a list of studies on CNTs used for asphalt modification. Most studies used up to 1.5% CNTs by weight of asphalt binder for a variety of asphalt types. Latifi and Hayati (2018) found that 1% is the optimised dosage of CNT in terms of dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) test results.
Most studies have utilised viscosity, penetration, softening point, complex modulus (G*), and phase angle (δ) to characterise CNT-modified asphalt’s property. All studies have shown that CNT-modified asphalt has higher viscosity and softening point, as well as lower penetration value than unmodified asphalt, which proves that CNT has “strengthening” and “reinforcing” effects on asphalt. It is well agreed that the addition of CNTs can improve rutting resistance by the evidence of exhibiting higher G*/sin δ value from DSR results. Tsantilis et al. (2018) attributed such a rutting resistance improvement to a network of CNTs formed within the asphalt that resulted in increasing amount of carbon and subsequent interaction with carbon molecules of asphalt in a microstructure.
Amin, El-Badawy, Breakah, and Ibrahim (2016) observed that fatigue cracking resistance is compromised by CNTs due to an increased fatigue parameter G*sin δ. However, G*sin δ parameter was reported not to capture the fatigue property of asphalt very well (Anderson et al., 2001; Yan et al., 2015). Therefore, other advanced testing may be needed to characterise true fatigue resistance of asphalt, particularly for CNTs-modified asphalt. Fracture energy and failure strain based on monotonic DSR test (Wu, 2017; Wu, 2018) could be such an advanced characterisation technique to characterise cracking resistance of asphalt. Another study by Ameri, Nowbakht, Molayem, and Aliha (2016) indicated that CNT can improve fatigue resistance, which was based on asphalt mixture testing using semi-circular bending fracture and beam fatigue test.

Road Materials and Pavement Design 11
Low-temperature property of asphalt is extremely important for cold regions where thermal cracking is a major distress for asphalt pavement. Bending beam rheometer (BBR) test is typically used to characterise low-temperature property based on a long-term aged asphalt simulated by pressure aging vessel (PAV). Lower stiffness and higher m-value which is a relaxation property obtained from the BBR test indicates a better thermal cracking resistance. De Melo, Triches, and De Rosso (2018) found that CNT worsens the asphalt’s stress relaxation ability at low temperature. However, Saltan, Terzi, and Karahancer (2018) concluded that CNT increases thermal cracking resistance by exhibiting a lower BBR stiffness for the CNT-modified asphalt. Strictly speaking, BBR stiffness alone cannot truly characterise asphalt’s low-temperature property. Another study by Latifi and Hayati (2018) revealed that CNT-modified asphalt results in a better thermal cracking resistance, which was based on the observation that higher strength is achieved for CNT-modified asphalt mixture. Whether strength can truly capture thermal cracking resistance of asphalt mixture is debatable, because excessively high strength for asphalt mixture may lead to a worsen relaxation property, i.e. insufficiently release thermal stress. Therefore, more studies relying on advanced characterisation techniques of fatigue cracking and thermal cracking properties for CNT-modified asphalt are needed.
3.2. Graphene nanoplatelets GNPs are comprised of short stacks of platelet-shaped graphene sheets that are identical to those found in the walls of CNTs, but in a planar form, as shown in Figure 2(c). They are 6–8 nm thick with a bulk density of 0.03–0.1 g/cm3, oxygen content of less than 1%, and carbon content of 99.5%. They are reported to have improved mechanical properties due to their unique size and morphology. Typical dosage for GNP in the asphalt ranges from 1 to 3% by weight of asphalt (Brcic, 2016; Han et al., 2018; Le, Marasteanu, & Turos, 2016; Le, Marasteanu, & Turos, 2019). Table 4 summarises a list of studies on GNPs used for asphalt modification.
Le et al. (2016, 2019) evaluated three types of GNPs (M750, M850, and 4827) from different manufacturers, and they found that no significant effect of GNPs is seen on complex modulus and phase angle, but GNPs can improve asphalt’s strength. The degree to strength increase is GNP type dependent. At the dosage of 3% in their studies, M750 type GNP can increase asphalt’s strength by 80%, while M850 type GNP improves the strength by 1.5 times and 4827-type GNP improves the strength by 1.3 times. They also found that 3% dosage of GNP is more cost effective than 6% in terms of asphalt strength improvement. Yan et al. (2015) also observed that GNP can increase asphalt’s strength significantly.
GNP can increase rutting resistance of asphalt binder, which is found by many researchers (Brcic, 2016; Le et al., 2016). For low-temperature property, Brcic (2016) concluded that GNP compromises thermal cracking resistance of asphalt binder, while Le et al. (2016, 2019) found that GNP-modified asphalt binder has superior flexural strength at low temperature. More researches are needed on the characterisation of low-temperature property of GNP-modified asphalt binder with regard to whether the strength improvement can truly add benefits to asphalt binders’ cracking resistance.
3.3. Graphene oxide GO is an exfoliated sheet containing only one or few layers of carbon atoms like graphene, however, it is not pristine graphene, as seen in Figure 2(d), but it contains oxygen functional group. The most attractive property of GO is that it can be reduced to graphene-like sheets by removing the oxygen-containing groups with the recovery of a conjugated structure (Pei & Cheng, 2012). GO is rich in oxygen-containing functional groups, making it reactive and

compatible with many polymer matrices (McAllister et al., 2007). Based on Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis, Le et al. (2016, 2019) observed that there is no chemical reaction between GO and asphalt. Through optical microscopy, Moreno-Navarro, Sol-Sánchez, Gámiz, and Rubio-Gámez (2018) found the presence of graphene flakes of different sizes and the shape of “bee” structure which is the aromatic molecules is different from original asphalt. They believed that the effect of graphene could be influenced by asphalt’s chemical composition, specifically, the ratio of polar and non-polar phase.
Table 5 summarises a list of studies on GO used for asphalt modification. Typical dosage of GO in asphalt modification ranges from 0.1% to 3% by weight. The addition of GO can improve asphalt’s rutting resistance, due to an increasing complex modulus and reduced phase angle for asphalt (Liu, Zhang, & Shi, 2018; Moreno-Navarro et al., 2018; Wu et al., 2017; Zeng, Wu, Pang, Sun, & Chen, 2017). For low-temperature property, Zeng et al. (2017) reported that GO can improve the low-temperature properties of asphalt before and after aging based on the observation that the complex modulus of GO-modified asphalt is much lower than the base asphalt at − 10°C. Li, Wu, and Amirkhanian (2018) had a similar finding that GO-modified exhibits higher m-value and lower BBR stiffness. However, Liu, Zhang, et al. (2018) stated that GO compromises the thermal cracking resistance of asphalt. Moreno-Navarro et al. (2018) also stated that GO increases the cracking risk and more susceptible to cracking due to brittleness.
High temperature and oxidation causes asphalt binder to age. Aging is an irreversible process with time. Zeng et al. (2017) found that GO can increase anti-aging property, but the improving effect is not so obvious. Moreno-Navarro et al. (2018) found that the addition of GO can help improve transferring heat. Liu, Zhang, et al. (2018) also found that GO does not remarkably change the transition temperature of asphalt, but can improve their crosslinking degree especially for non-modified asphalt.
Liu, Zhang, Wu, Muhunthan, and Shi (2018) pointed out that there are two limitations in the modification of asphalt via GO: one is that GO can increase asphalt’s viscosity, which is unfavourable for mixing and paving of asphalt mixture and may cause more energy consumption and airborne emissions; the other is GO is detrimental to asphalt’s thermal cracking resistance. Therefore, they proposed to improve the performance of asphalt modified not only by GO but also by warm mix asphalt additives and waste cooking oil. They found that incorporation of GO and Sasobit warm mix asphalt additive into asphalt can result in excellent high-temperature properties, which rendered it more suitable for hot-climate regions. In addition, incorporation of GO and waste cooking oil into asphalt can improve the low-temperature properties of asphalt binder, which could be applicable in cold climatic regions. It seems that the combination of graphene family nanomaterials with other additives such as warm mix asphalt, rejuvenators, waste engine oil, and waste cooking oil may achieve desirable performance requirement, which requires further investigations.

sections.heading: 4. Handling and blending carbon and graphene family nanomaterials with asphalt
sections.text: Previous study shows that a simple paddle mixing is sufficient to disperse nanomaterial (nanoclay) into sol and gel type asphalt at high temperature (Bagshaw, Kemmitt, Waterland, & Brooke, 2019). It is extremely important to understand the dispersion of nanomaterials to achieve uniform composite materials. Graphene family nanomaterials are light weighted and thin, which raises the concern of handling them and is notoriously worrisome by detrimental effects they may have on health. Chatterjee, Yang, and Choi (2016) evaluated the differential genotoxic and epigentoxic effects of graphene family nanomaterials in human bronchial epithelial cells, and they concluded that subtle changes in gene expression could be caused. Ma-Hock et al. (2013) found that no adverse effects are observed after inhalation exposure to 10 mg/m3 GNPs. It is generally

sections.heading: 16 S. Wu and O. Tahri
sections.text:
believed that graphene is chemically and thermally stable, and therefore it is not a hazardous material. However, cautions should be taken when handling graphene family nanomaterials to avoid skin, eye, and respiratory tract irritation. Researchers are recommended to check and follow the local authority’s compliance and policy on the use of graphene family nanomaterials.
The density of CNT is 2.1 g/cm3 while the bulk density of multi-wall CNTs is as low as 0.065 g/cm3 (Santagata, Baglieri, Tsantilis, Chiappinelli, & Aimonetto, 2015). Such low bulk density creates difficulties in handling during mixing with asphalt (Moreno-Navarro et al., 2018). Du, Bai, and Cheng (2007) pointed out that there exists a challenge to mix CNT in polymer composite and form a uniformly dispersed polymer matrix. For any modified asphalt, it is important to achieve a uniform and well-dispersed matrix. The mechanical shear mixing process is a common practice to mix modifiers or additives with asphalt, which is applicable for graphene family nanomaterials modified asphalt, as shown in Tables 3–5. Essentially, graphene is mixed with base asphalt at evaluated temperature and with high stirring speed for a significant amount of time using a high-speed shearing device. The mixing temperature of 150–170°C would be appropriate for most asphalt binders; higher temperature and higher stirring speed may be needed if a harder base binder or higher dosage of graphene is used. However, an excessively high temperature could cause additional aging for asphalt as well as cause mass loss for graphene if the temperature reaches above 500°C (Du et al., 2007).
In order to achieve a more homogenous dispersion, Santagata et al. (2015) proposed to insert ultrasonic homogeniser into the blend of CNTs and asphalt where the generated ultrasound separates nanoparticles to avoid agglomerates. Based on a series of rheological properties evaluation, they found that the CNT-modified asphalt by sonication exhibits superior performance than that by mechanical shearing. They believed that the damage to outer shells of nanotubes is negligible and does not jeopardise the beneficial effects of agglomerate disaggregation. Hasan, Kamran, Mohammad, Ahmad, and Hosein (2012) compared different mixes on the blending of graphene and asphalt, and they recommended to use an ultrasonic mixer because it could result in a homogenous blending.
In a study by Faramarzi, Arabani, Haghi, and Mottaghitalab (2015), they dispersed CNTs into kerosene solvent by sonication, which was called “wet process”. The CNTs-kerosene compound could be stored with high stability for two weeks, and it can be added into asphalt later when it is ready to use. Although the wet process is an efficient technique to mix CNTs into asphalt, it may soften asphalt due to the residue of kerosene without being completely evaporated. Shirakawa, Tada, and Okazaki (2012) used asphalt emulsion as a solvent to disperse CNTs and found that CNTs disperse in anionic and non-ionic emulsion better than cationic emulsion. The CNTs-modified binder showed higher penetration and short wave absorption than carbon powder modified asphalt binder. Using advanced techniques to analyse the dispersion needs further exploration whether atomic force miscopy (AFM) or FTIR can be effectively used to characterise the presence of nanomaterials in the asphalt (Bagshaw et al., 2019; Leiva-Villacorta & Vargas-Nordcbeck, 2019).

sections.heading: 5. Cost–benefits for using carbon and graphene family nanomaterials
sections.text:
As carbon and graphene family nanomaterials are newly developed and innovative materials, their costs are dependent on the complexity of the manufacturing process. High cost would be the most significant obstacle for application in asphalt industry. Asphalt and asphalt mixture cost is varying, which can be hundreds of dollars per ton (Lippert, Wu, & Ozer, 2017). Carbon and graphene family nanomaterials CNT, GNP, and GO are typically used at an optimised dosage of 1%, 1%, and 0.05%, respectively, according to literature review and Tables 3–5. Table 6 presents the calculation of the cost per ton of each nanomaterial-modified asphalt mixture. According to

In this case, GNP is benchmark with a relative cost of 1.
Le et al. (2016), the unit price for GNP is $6000 to $8000 per ton, and in this case the cost for GNP-modified asphalt mixture is as low as $9 to $12 per ton. Based on relative cost analysis in Table 6, compared to GNP (benchmark), the relative cost of CNT and GO is 79–2268 and 709– 3402, respectively. This is to say, out of all these nanomaterials, GO is the most expensive and all carbon and graphene family materials cost more than a typical asphalt mixture, therefore they are not economically feasible option for asphalt modification as far as now. With an increasing market of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials and technology development, the unit price is expected to decrease and thus rendering it more appealing to use those nanomaterials into asphalt modification.
In particular, a study by Arabani and Faramarzi (2015) estimated cost–benefit for 0.5% CNTmodified asphalt mixture, which is shown in Table 7. Their calculation is based on the principle that the resilient modulus parameter is one of the material inputs in the current AASHTO design guide. Based on the fact that 0.5% CNT-modified asphalt mixture has improved resilient modulus than traditional non-modified asphalt mixture, which results in a reduced calculated pavement thickness, and consequently decreased costs with respect to the energy consumption of asphalt production, materials (aggregates and bitumen), production, repair and maintenance. The cost benefit of using carbon and graphene family nanomaterials should be further evaluated using life-cycle cost analysis or other analysis tools to demonstrate the economic feasibility.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: Since carbon and graphene family nanomaterials are relatively innovative materials used for asphalt modification, some challenges still exist on their efficiency in mass production and wide

sections.heading: 18 S. Wu and O. Tahri
sections.text:
application in the asphalt industry. However, with more promising manufacturing technologies, low cost and good quality of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials will be available.
As far as asphalt binder modification, CNT is the most studied modifier, followed by GO and GNPs. The optimised dosage for CNT, GO, and GNP is dependents on the asphalt type and desired performance to obtain. Typical dosages for each nanomaterial are summarised through Tables 3–5. In most studies, CNTs are used up to 1.5% by weight of asphalt for a variety of asphalt types. Typical dosage of GO in asphalt modification ranges from 0.1% to 3% by weight. Typical dosage for GNP ranges from 1 to 3% by weight.
Agreements are made regarding the effect of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials on the asphalt binders’ high-temperature properties. The carbon and graphene family nanomaterials have reinforcing effects on the modified asphalt binder at high temperature, which have repeatedly observed by researchers showing higher viscosity and complex modulus but lower penetration value. This will be beneficial for improving the rutting resistance of asphalt binders.
However, the effect of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials on fatigue cracking and thermal cracking resistance of asphalt binders are not well agreed. It seems that carbon and graphene family nanomaterials tends to compromise the cracking resistance of asphalt binders due to higher stiffness, brittleness, and lower stress relaxation capability. It seems to exhibit antiaging resistance but not well studied, especially the long-term performance of asphalt binders with optimised dosage of varying carbon and graphene family nanomaterials.
Carbon and graphene family nanomaterials’ compatibility with asphalt is critical for the performance of asphalt binder. Graphene has low bulk density and the dispersion of graphene into asphalt is challenging to obtain uniform graphene-modified asphalt. Using high-speed shearing device at elevated temperature followed by inserting ultrasonic homogeniser into the blend of graphene and asphalt has been found to be the best solution, where the generated ultrasound separates nanoparticles to avoid agglomerates. Advanced characterisation techniques such as AFM or FTIR would be needed to characterise the dispersion of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials into the asphalt.
For future study on the carbon and graphene family nanomaterials for asphalt modification, emphasis should be placed on characterisation of resistance to fatigue cracking and thermal cracking with advanced laboratory characterisation techniques. The correlation of microstructure and monopoly to the rheological properties and performance of asphalt binders would be needed to understand from both microstructure’s and mechanistic stand point of view. The combination of carbon and graphene family nanomaterials with other additives such as warm mix asphalt, rejuvenators, and waste engine oil could be further explored to enhance feasible and green asphalt technology and practice. The life-cycle cost analysis and life-cycle assessment are also suggested to better demonstrate the cost benefit and environmental impact reduction of using these innovative carbon and graphene family nanomaterials.

It is interesting to note that researchers produced graphene using asphalt as a carbon source (Liu et al., 2014), and other inexpensive carbon-rich materials can be also used for the CVD method.

Chemical vapour deposition Petroleum asphalt or materials that are carbon-rich • Inexpensive source • Efficient • Hazardous chemicals • Dissolve asphalt in toluene for 1 h • Immerse pretreated nickel foam in the asphalt-toluene solution for 1 h • Dry out toluene with flowing Ar and H2 • Heat the quartz tube to 940°C for 10 min • Cool down to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/min, then synthesise 3D graphene Liu et al. (2014)
Exfoliation Graphite • Simple procedure • No mass production Mechanical exfoliation: • Peeled from highly oriented pyrolytic graphite using scotch tape Gayathri et al. (2014)

Unzipping Multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) • Large-scale production • Impurity results in electronic property inferior • Suspend MWCNTs in sulphuric acid • Treat with KMnO4 for 1 h at room temperature and 1 h at 55–70°C • Unzipping occurs in a linear longitudinal cut to form nanoribbon, depending on diameter and number of layers of starting MWCNTs Kosynkin et al. (2009)
